title.narrative: The Inclusive Dairy Enterprise project for Uganda (TIDE)

description.narrative: The Inclusive Dairy Enterprise project (TIDE) is an initiative of SNV in collaboration with WUR CDI the Friesian DDA (Dairy Development Authority). The duration of this project is from October 2015 until December 2019 and it is submitted to the Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands (EKN) in Uganda. The impact of this project is poverty reduction through improved dairy farm incomes household nutrition and employment opportunities for 20000 farmers. The Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands in Uganda has supported investment in the cold chain in the South Western milk shed by installing 100 milk coolers. The Inclusive Dairy Enterprise (TIDE) project enables small and medium-sized dairy farmers and their organisations to leverage on these investments by strengthening the milk value chain to improve their incomes and the nutritional status of their families in six districts in South-West Uganda. The TIDE project contributes to poverty reduction in South West Uganda by supporting agricultural transformation. Using the drive of the private sector which has expanded processing capacity more dairy farms can connect to the dairy value chain. The expanding milk markets both in and outside Uganda can be served by improving the quality and seasonality of dairy production. The focus will be on small and medium dairy farms to ensure that women and youth benefit from this transformation. The project has four components to achieve its objectives:1. Improved dairy farm productivity2. Improved commercial milk quality3. Improved pro-active dairy regulation4. Improved dairy household nutrition The challenges to strengthen the dairy value chain in Uganda are basically threefold: • Strengthen the cooperative• Improve production by increasing productivity per cow• Increase farmers’ income by increasing the milk price at farm gate level Although these three issues are obviously interlinked Agriterra believes there is a clear division of tasks possible: SNV WUR CDI and the Friesian have extensive (technical) know-how on what’s needed to increase productivity. Added value of Agriterra is to strengthen the structures (cooperative) to embed this knowledge in a sustainable way and second to increase milk prices at farm level. This can be done by increasing milk volumes and by adding value to the milk (processing).

Within the overall TIDE project framework Agriterra will particularly focus on:- Leading the project activity supporting the dairy cooperative societies in southwest Uganda to improve their functioning and moving them to become bankable where possible,- Strengthening the extension component of the TIDE project by providing practical dairy farming expertise.Agriterra will implement that role by making available local and expatriate staff mobilising expert missions from its Agripool and in general linking its extensive network of dairy contacts in The Netherlands to relevant project activities and components. 2017 Agriterra is involved in cooperative engagement supports cooperative development for dairy farmers. The approach involves three levels of engagement i.e.
- a selected group of cooperatives (23 so far but increasing to 35) has an intensive support and training programme aiming to diversify the range of services provided to farmers,
- a larger group of cooperatives (73) is not part of the pre-selected group but acquired a milk cooler under the aBi project: this group will be supported with targeted training and support to strengthen operations (this is funded by aBi),
- the remaining cooperatives (approx. 70) does not have specific support yet but during this year some of the products will be made available to them on a demand basis.
While so far this component has been supply-driven during this year a shift will be made towards a more market-based approach involving packaging project offerings in products that can be accessed on demand (also gradually involving cost-sharing). Products include governance financial management and business development with methodologies including training and coaching mentoring.
Goals: - 12 bankable cooperatives
2018: In addition to agriterra's core mandate in TIDE project, improving cooperative governance financial management and business development Agriterra will focus on the uptake of the following cooperative specific products. - 29 milk cooler distribution and placement - Fodder and silage, Coops supports farmers to 1. Clear land and fence, 2. Plough and harrow, 3. Cultivate fodder/ pasture, 4. Harvest and conserve, 5. Store (silage + hay)- 30 Cooperatives - Silage/ Hay making youth group, Supporting cooperative societies with forming youth groups to make silage for members- Target 30 cooperatives - Mechanization, cooperatives access equipment to supplement the tractors from the NAADS clusters - Target 10 cooperatives
- Water for production, Coops engage contractor to develop on-farm water facilities (tailor-made)- Target 5 clusters - Cooperative Digitization, Coops digitalise dairy records and milk payments- Target 30 cooperatives Goal: 45 bankable cooperatives 2019 The Inclusive Dairy Enterprise project (TIDE)
Cooperative Development Unit (CDU) 2019 Goals
Governance: Many of the bankable cooperatives are now able to watch and guard against bad
governance. To safeguard against wastage as well as fraud internal control structures need to be
strengthened by putting in place internal Audit functions/ Supervisory committees and adherence
to regulations especially in the areas of conducting Annual audits and General Meetings.
In addition collaboration between cooperatives will be supported. Most of the cooperatives were
initiated to qualify for acquiring milk chilling equipment. But for effective marketing cooperatives
start realizing that it makes more sense to be a big cooperative with several milk collection centers spread around the community rather than having several small cooperatives each owning their own cooler. The need to work together and effecting the cooperative principle of Cooperating among Cooperatives will be
given high priority in cooperative extension in 2019 so that not only the cooperatives benefit from economies of scale but also buyers/processors easily get the supply they require.
Financial Management: Support to improved record keeping and generally Financial
Management has necessitated the need to digitize most of the transactions at the cooperatives.
The plan to also roll out the Quality Based milk Payment System calls for computerization of most
of the work. Further training and coaching/mentoring will include support to cooperatives in
acquiring both Hard and Software in this process of digitization.
Cooperative business performance is greatly affected by poor business at farm level. Most of the
farms are not yet close to performing at optimum levels as far as milk production is concerned and
hence milk coolers cannot fill up during dry seasons. Access to affordable credit/capital for on farm
investment is a bottleneck and linkage to SACCOs for possible partnership with producer
cooperatives shall be the major focus in 2019.
Business Case Development: Both in order to strengthen member commitment and loyalty but
also for its own business case (to get milk coolers to benefit from increased production)
cooperatives will be encouraged to act as a channel for services and products which can assist its
members to increase productivity. This could also involve the cooperative playing a role itself in
service provision either through affiliated service providers (youth groups) or dedicated business
units (farm mechanization).
Access to better markets is number one agenda for most of the bankable cooperatives. The feeling
that the current market is unstable/unreliable is a key challenge to strategic planning and
budgeting processes. Strategic partnerships with processors and investment partners shall be prioritized.
Co-operative based extension
The main project approaches to stimulating learning are through the PDTFs and the promotion of cooperative societies.
In the absence of government plans for effective extension services the value chain actors may need to
take up that role. As part of potential collaboration with Amos Dairy the TIDE project piloted dairy
cooperative societies to employ extension officers. While Amos withdrew from the pilot TIDE is continuing
with the pilot for now.
Inclusive business models
The aim of this theme is to document and share lessons learned from working with cooperative societies (both as value chain actors and value chain supporters) and to assess other models of smallholder inclusion as an input to wider policy discussions on improving and enabling the environment for inclusive dairy development. During the inception trends were studied in input service provision relationships between smallholder farmers and cooperatives dairy processors input suppliers and service providers. Also a conceptual framework was developed for an inventory of the various ‘inclusive’ models in Kenya Ethiopia and Uganda. During 2019 the field research will be combined with learning and exchange events within the East African context to result in White Papers (one for each country) sharing the lessons learned including recommendations or guidelines for stimulating and professionalizing dairy cooperatives.

Within the overall TIDE project framework Agriterra will particularly focus on:- Leading the project activity supporting the dairy cooperative societies in southwest Uganda to improve their functioning and moving them to become bankable where possible,- Strengthening the extension component of the TIDE project by providing practical dairy farming expertise.Agriterra will implement that role by making available local and expatriate staff mobilising expert missions from its Agripool and in general linking its extensive network of dairy contacts in The Netherlands to relevant project activities and components. Initial proposal is to have 7 missions in 2016:3 advisory with 2 experts (including 1 mission for company assessments)3 technical with 2 farmers At the end of 2016 a mission for ‘evaluation’ is requested and can be invoiced 100%.And full time availability of Emile in Mbarara being part of the TIDE team on Cooperative Development. The rest of the budget will be on 50/50 basis.
